contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox language family |name=Igboid |region=South central Nigeria, lower reaches of the [[Niger River]] and east, south the [[Benue River|Benue]] |familycolor=Niger-Congo |fam2=[[Atlantic–Congo]] |fam3=[[Volta–Niger]] |fam4= [[YEAI|{{smallcaps all|YEAI}}]] |child1=[[Igbo languages|Igbo]] |child2=''[[Ekpeye language|Ekpeye]]'' |sil=17-2095 }} '''Igboid languages''' constitute a branch of the [[Volta–Niger]] language family. It includes Ekpeye and the Igbo languages: *[[Ekpeye language|Ekpeye]] *Igbo: [[Igbo language|Igbo]] proper, [[Ikwerre language|Ikwerre]], [[Ika language (Nigeria)|Ika]], [[Izi language|Izii]]–[[Ikwo language|Ikwo]]–[[Ezza language|Ezza]]–[[Mgbo language|Mgbo]], [[Ogba language|Ogba]], and [[Ukwuani-Aboh-Ndoni language|Ukwuani-Aboh-Ndoni]], spoken mainly in southern [[Nigeria]]. [[Kay Williamson|Williamson]] and [[Roger Blench|Blench]] conclude that the Igbo languages (Igboid apart from Ekpeye) form a "language cluster" and that they are somewhat [[mutually intelligible]].<ref>{{cite book | last=Williamson | first=Kay | coauthors=Roger M. Blench | title=African languages: an introduction | publisher=Cambridge University Press | year=2000}}</ref> However, mutual intelligibility is only marginal, even among the Izii–Ikwo–Ezaa–Mgbo languages.<ref>[http://www.sil.org/iso639-3/cr_files/2012-078.pdf]</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}} * [http://www.ethnologue.com/show_family.asp?subid=2109-16 Ethnologue Language Tree: Igboid] {{Igbo topics}} [[Category:Igboid languages| ]] {{nc-lang-stub}}
